column2: Forward were the crew; some asleep, others smoking, others playing cards.
column3: Forward were the crew; some asleep, others smoking, others playing cards.

column2: The fourth member of the party, Melick, was seated near the mainmast, folding some papers in a peculiar way.
column3: The fourth member of the party, Melick, was seated near the mainmast, folding some papers in a peculiar way.

column2: His occupation at length attracted the roving eyes of Featherstone, who poked forth his head from his hammock, and said in a sleepy voice:
column3: His occupation at length attracted the roving eyes of Featherstone, who poked forth his head from his hammock, and said in a sleepy voice:

column2: By Jove! you're the only one aboard that's busy.
column3: By Jove! you're the only one aboard that's busy.

column2: What are you doing?"
column3: What are you doing?"

column2: Paper boats, said Melick, in a business-like tone.
column3: Paper boats, said Melick, in a business like tone.

column2: Paper boats!	Paper boats!
What for?
column3: What for?

column2: Anything to kill time, you know.
column3: Anything to kill time, you know.

column2: By Jove! exclaimed Featherstone again, raising himself higher in his hammock, "that's not a bad idea.
column3: By Jove! exclaimed Featherstone again, raising himself higher in his hammock, "that's not a bad idea.

column2: By Jove! glowious! glowious!
column3: By Jove! glowious! glowious!

column2: I say, Oxenden, did you hear that?"
column3: I say, Oxenden, did you hear that?"

column2: Oh, I mean a race with these paper boats.	Oh, I mean a race with these paper boats.
We can bet on them, you know."
column3: We can bet on them, you know."

column2: At this Featherstone sat upright, with his legs dangling out of the hammock.
column3: At this Featherstone sat upright, with his legs dangling out of the hammock.

column2: By Jove! he exclaimed again.
column3: By Jove! he exclaimed again.

column2: So we can.
column3: So we can.

column2: Do you know, Melick, old chap, I think that's a wegular piece of inspiration. A wegatta! and we can bet on the best boat."
column3: Do you know, Melick, old chap, I think that's a wegular piece of inspiration. A wegatta! and we can bet on the best boat."

column2: Well, you know, that's the fun of it, said Melick, who went solemnly on as he spoke, folding his paper boats; "that's the fun of it.
column3: Well, you know, that's the fun of it, said Melick, who went solemnly on as he spoke, folding his paper boats; "that's the fun of it.

column2: For you see if there was a wind we should be going on ourselves, and the regatta couldn't come off; but, as it is, the water is just right. You pick out your boat, and lay your bet on her to race to some given point."
column3: For you see if there was a wind we should be going on ourselves, and the regatta couldn't come off; but, as it is, the water is just right. You pick out your boat, and lay your bet on her to race to some given point."

column2: A given point?	A given point?
Oh, easily enough; something or anything--a bubble'll do, or we can pitch out a bit of wood.
column3: Oh, easily enough; something or anything-a bubble'll do, or we can pitch out a bit of wood.

column2: Upon this Featherstone descended from his perch, and came near to examine the proceedings, while the other two, eager to take advantage of the new excitement, soon joined him.
column3: Upon this Featherstone descended from his perch, and came near to examine the proceedings, while the other two, eager to take advantage of the new excitement, soon joined him.

column2: By this time Melick had finished his paper boats.
column3: By this time Melick had finished his paper boats.

column2: There were four of them, and they were made of different colors, namely, red, green, yellow, and white.
column3: There were four of them, and they were made of different colors, namely, red, green, yellow, and white.

column2: I'll put these in the water, said Melick, "and then we can lay our bets on them as we choose.
column3: I'll put these in the water, said Melick, "and then we can lay our bets on them as we choose.

column2: But first let us see if there is anything that can be taken as a point of arrival.
column3: But first let us see if there is anything that can be taken as a point of arrival.

column2: If there isn't anything, I can pitch out a bit of wood, in any direction which may seem best."
column3: If there isn't anything, I can pitch out a bit of wood, in any direction which may seem best."

column2: Saying this, he went to the side, followed by the others, and all looked out carefully over the water.
column3: Saying this, he went to the side, followed by the others, and all looked out carefully over the water.

column2: There's a black speck out there, said Oxenden.
column3: There's a black speck out there, said Oxenden.

column2: That'll do.	That'll do.
I wonder what it is?"

column2: Probably the spar of some ship.
column3: Probably the spar of some ship.

column2: Oh, it's a spar, said Melick.

column2: It's one end of it, the rest is under water.
column3: It's one end of it, the rest is under water.

column2: The spot thus chosen was a dark, circular object, about a hundred yards away, and certainly did look very much like the extremity of some spar, the rest of which was under water.
column3: The spot thus chosen was a dark, circular object, about a hundred yards away, and certainly did look very much like the extremity of some spar, the rest of which was under water.

column2: After this the four stood watching the little fleet in silence.
column3: After this the four stood watching the little fleet in silence.

column2: Gradually they drew apart, the green one drifting astern, the yellow one remaining under the vessel, while the red and the white were carried out in the direction where they were expected to go, with about a foot of space between them.
column3: Gradually they drew apart, the green one drifting astern, the yellow one remaining under the vessel, while the red and the white were carried out in the direction where they were expected to go, with about a foot of space between them.

column2: Two to one on the red! cried Featherstone, betting on the one which had gained the lead.
column3: Two to one on the red! cried Featherstone, betting on the one which had gained the lead.

column2: Oxenden made the same bet, which was taken by Melick and the doctor.
column3: Oxenden made the same bet, which was taken by Melick and the doctor.

column2: All took part in this; the excitement rose high and the betting went on merrily.
column3: All took part in this; the excitement rose high and the betting went on merrily.

column2: At length it was noticed that the white was overhauling the red.
column3: At length it was noticed that the white was overhauling the red.

column2: The excitement grew intense; the betting changed its form, but was still kept up, until at last the two paper boats seemed blended together in one dim spot which gradually faded out of sight.
column3: The excitement grew intense; the betting changed its form, but was still kept up, until at last the two paper boats seemed blended together in one dim spot which gradually faded out of sight.

column2: It was now necessary to determine the state of the race, so Featherstone ordered out the boat.
column3: It was now necessary to determine the state of the race, so Featherstone ordered out the boat.

column2: The four were soon embarked, and the men rowed out toward the point which had been chosen as the end of the race.
column3: The four were soon embarked, and the men rowed out toward the point which had been chosen as the end of the race.

column2: An animated discussion arose about this.
column3: An animated discussion arose about this.

column2: Some of the bets were off, but others remained an open question, and each side insisted upon a different view of the case.
column3: Some of the bets were off, but others remained an open question, and each side insisted upon a different view of the case.

column2: In the midst of this, Featherstone's attention was drawn to the dark spot already mentioned as the goal of the race.
column3: In the midst of this, Featherstone's attention was drawn to the dark spot already mentioned as the goal of the race.

column2: Pull up, lads, a little; let's see what it is.	Pull up, lads, a little; let's see what it is.
It doesn't look to me like a spar."

column2: The others, always on the lookout for some new object of interest, were attracted by these words, and looked closely at the thing in question.

column2: The men pulled.

column2: The boat drew nearer.

column2: It's not a spar, said Melick, who was at the bow.

column2: He failed to get it, and did no more than touch it.
column3: He failed to get it, and did no more than touch it.

column2: It moved easily and sank, but soon came up again.
column3: It moved easily and sank, but soon came up again.

column2: A second time he grasped at it, and with both hands. This time he caught it, and then lifted it out of the water into the boat.
column3: A second time he grasped at it, and with both hands. This time he caught it, and then lifted it out of the water into the boat.

column2: These proceedings had been watched with the deepest interest; and now, as this curious floating thing made its appearance among them, they all crowded around it in eager excitement.
column3: These proceedings had been watched with the deepest interest; and now, as this curious floating thing made its appearance among them, they all crowded around it in eager excitement.

column2: It looks like a can of preserved meat, said the doctor.
column3: It looks like a can of preserved meat, said the doctor.

column2: It certainly is a can, said Melick, "for it's made of metal; but as to preserved meat, I have my doubts."
column3: It certainly is a can, said Melick, "for it's made of metal; but as to preserved meat, I have my doubts."

column2: The article in question was made of metal and was cylindrical in shape.
column3: The article in question was made of metal and was cylindrical in shape.

column2: It was soldered tight and evidently contained something.
column3: It was soldered tight and evidently contained something.

column2: The nature of the metal was not easily perceptible, for it was coated with slime, and covered over about half its surface with barnacles and sea-weed.
column3: The nature of the metal was not easily perceptible, for it was coated with slime, and covered over about half its surface with barnacles and sea weed.

column2: It's some kind of preserved meat, said the doctor.
column3: It's some kind of preserved meat, said the doctor.

They pot all sorts of things now."

column2: It must have been floating for ages."

column2: So come, let's open it, and see what sort of diet the antediluvians had."
column3: So come, let's open it, and see what sort of diet the antediluvians had."

column2: It's odd, too.

column2: I never saw anything like it before.

column3: Upon this Melick took the cylinder, turned it upside down, shook it smartly, and then lifted it and pounded it against the deck.

column2: This served to loosen the contents, which seemed tightly packed, but came gradually down until at length they could be seen and drawn forth. Melick drew them forth, and the contents of the mysterious copper cylinder resolved themselves into two packages.
column3: This served to loosen the contents, which seemed tightly packed, but came gradually down until at length they could be seen and drawn forth. Melick drew them forth, and the contents of the mysterious copper cylinder resolved themselves into two packages.

column2: Melick opened the package, and it was seen that Featherstone had lost. There were no jewels, but one or two sheets of something that looked like paper.

column2: These sheets were covered with writing.

column2: Why, this is English!

column2: There were three sheets, all covered with writing--one in English, another in French, and a third in German.
column3: There were three sheets, all covered with writing-one in English, another in French, and a third in German.

column2: It was as follows:
column3: It was as follows:

column2: To the finder of this:	To the finder of this:

Sir,--I am an Englishman, and have been carried by a series of incredible events to a land from which escape is as impossible as from the grave.	Sir,--I am an Englishman, and have been carried by a series of incredible events to a land from which escape is as impossible as from the grave.
I have written this and committed it to the sea, in the hope that the ocean currents may bear it within the reach of civilized man.
column3: I have written this and committed it to the sea, in the hope that the ocean currents may bear it within the reach of civilized man.

column2: Oh, unknown friend! whoever you are.
column3: Oh, unknown friend! whoever you are.

column2: I entreat you to let this message be made known in some way to my father, Henry More, Keswick, Cumberland, England, so that he may learn the fate of his son.
column3: I entreat you to let this message be made known in some way to my father, Henry More, Keswick, Cumberland, England, so that he may learn the fate of his son.

column2: ADAM MORE.
column3: ADAM MORE.

column3: This other package must be the manuscript, said Oxenden, "and it'll tell all about it."
